issue.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> @Frauschi Can you please take a look at the [Zephyr test failure](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/runs/8086936503/job/22097805629?pr=1710)? It looks like an out-of-storage error to me, and I'm unsure of the best way to resolve it. The same test fails on the current `main`, so it's not specific to this PR.

Indeed, what does "No space left on device" mean in this context? Also FYI, @Frauschi we're aiming of doing a `liboqs` release containing this PR early next week so resolving this quickly would be very helpful & appreciated.

issue.title: Implementation of Composite Sig
issue.body:
This is an implementation of the version 10 [Composite Signatures For Use In Internet PKI](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/).
Current status of this work:
- I'm working on fixing the issues pointed by the Git Actions workflow tests.
- There will be alterations to update this for version 11 when it is released.
- To be precise with the IETF draft, we need to wait for ML-DSA-ipd to be implemented.

comment.body: One more thought, @feventura : This is such a significant addition to `oqsprovider` that  I'd like to ask you to please consider adding yourself [to the contributors list](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider?tab=readme-ov-file#team) while addressing the issues (and re-basing to main as CI now should "turn green" also on the PR).

issue.title: Documentation fails to build corrrectly

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working; high priority to fix

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
```text
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/sig/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/
Generating XML output for the main page
/Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/README.md:17: error: unable to resolve reference to 'linuxmacos' for \ref command
Running plantuml with JAVA...
type lookup cache used 152/65536 hits=476 misses=152
symbol lookup cache used 186/65536 hits=566 misses=186
finished...
Exiting...
FAILED: CMakeFiles/gen_docs /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/build/CMakeFiles/gen_docs 
cd /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs && /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/scripts/run_doxygen.sh /opt/local/bin/doxygen /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/docs/.Doxyfile /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/build
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```


**To Reproduce**
Clone and run the build.


**Expected behavior**
Successful generation of docs, of course.

Like
```text
Generating XML output for page options-for-configuring-liboqs-builds
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/common/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/kem/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/common/rand/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/sig/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/
Generating XML output for the main page
Running plantuml with JAVA...
type lookup cache used 152/65536 hits=476 misses=152
symbol lookup cache used 186/65536 hits=566 misses=186
finished...

real	0m0.698s
user	0m0.159s
sys	0m0.108s

Built Doxygen documentation
```


**Fix**
_Note: fix includes updating `.Doxygen` to conform to v1.9.8._

```diff
diff --git a/README.md b/README.md
index 7a51186fe..f9b49615d 100644
--- a/README.md
+++ b/README.md
@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ liboqs is an open source C library for quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms.
                - [Limitations and Security](#limitations-and-security)
                        - [Platform limitations](#platform-limitations)
        - [Quickstart](#quickstart)
-               - [Linux/macOS](#linuxmacos)
+               - [Linux/macOS](#linux/macOS)
                - [Windows](#windows)
                - [Cross compilation](#cross-compilation)
        - [Documentation](#documentation)
```

and please do
```sh
$ cd docs
$ doxygen -u .Doxyfile
```

comment.body:
> Even after my patch?! Are you sure the appropriate files are changed? Maybe it gets stale version from somewhere - because after my patch is applied there should be (there **isn't**) text `linuxmacos` anymore, anywhere in the file.

Indeed -- there was a `cmake` cache. After cleaning it, everything works now. Thanks for providing a solution! But it seems `doxygen` 1.9.3 also works OK, even without the "Doxyfile" update: All it needs is the change to the link target ("linuxmacos"->"linux/macOS"). Do you want to do the PR or shall I do it?

issue.title: p384_mlkem1024 hybrid added
issue.body:
We would like to use a NIST P curve + ML-KEM hybrid and compliance reasons would mandate using P-384 and ML-KEM-1024.
We found that P-384 is the most accepted P-curve. See [CNSA 1.0](https://media.defense.gov/2021/Sep/27/2002862527/-1/-1/0/CNSS%20WORKSHEET.PDF).
From the ML-KEM variants, level 5 will be the most widely accepted. See [CNSA 2.0](https://media.defense.gov/2022/Sep/07/2003071834/-1/-1/0/CSA_CNSA_2.0_ALGORITHMS_.PDF).
Having a P-384 + ML-KEM-1024 hybrid could be useful.

comment.body: Hi @baentsch, as far as we know there is no draft for this combination. The reason I included our oid in the pull request is to provide a fixed oid, just to make sure it doesn't constantly change in oqs-provider. We intended for this oid to be permanent, until (and if) it is standardized. Of course any other oid would suffice.

issue.title: Document & curate (O)IDs
issue.body:
The file [oqs-template/generate.yml](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/oqs-template/generate.yml) serves as the master file for all algorithm (O)IDs. Due to the absence of standard documents specifying them, most of the IDs chosen are randomly allocated, many manually, many automatically.

As persistence of PQC signature algorithms is a default feature of `oqsprovider`, OIDs for signature algorithms are manually curated and updated as OID updates are required, e.g., due to algorithm updates.

As persistence of PQC KEM algorithms is a non-default feature of `oqsprovider`, OIDs for KEM algorithms are mostly automatically generated and therefore not stable across releases.

This issue is to propose changing this with at least the following improvements:
- Document the origin for each (O)ID
- Change automatic OID allocation for KEM algorithms to manually curated allocation, paving the way for making [OQS_KEM_ENCODERS](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/CONFIGURE.md#oqs_kem_encoders) a default feature

comment.body:
> May I propose @bhess takes on responsibility for managing the Kyber/Dilithium/ML-KEM/ML-DSA ID range and resolve this particular conundrum?

We have the following Kyber-r3 OIDs registered under the IBM tree, which could be used:
- Kyber512: 1.3.6.1.4.1.2.267.8.2.2
- Kyber768: 1.3.6.1.4.1.2.267.8.3.3
- Kyber1024: 1.3.6.1.4.1.2.267.8.4.4

The Dilithium and ML-DSA-ipd OIDs are correctly reflected in https://github.com/IETF-Hackathon/pqc-certificates/blob/master/docs/oid_mapping.md

issue.body:
We would like to use a NIST P curve + ML-KEM hybrid and compliance reasons would mandate using P-384 and ML-KEM-1024.
We found that P-384 is the most accepted P-curve. See [CNSA 1.0](https://media.defense.gov/2021/Sep/27/2002862527/-1/-1/0/CNSS%20WORKSHEET.PDF).
From the ML-KEM variants, level 5 will be the most widely accepted. See [CNSA 2.0](https://media.defense.gov/2022/Sep/07/2003071834/-1/-1/0/CSA_CNSA_2.0_ALGORITHMS_.PDF).
Having a P-384 + ML-KEM-1024 hybrid could be useful.

comment.body:
> We intended for this oid to be permanent, until (and if) it is standardized. Of course any other oid would suffice.

OK -- understood & makes sense. Please feel free to amend the PR by comment to state this (at the top of "generate.yml" or next to the OID). Otherwise, `git blame` will allow us to trace this in the future. A re-base to "main" would be nice to get CI to turn green, though.

issue.title: remove references to unsupported openssh [skip ci]
issue.body:
This removes no longer warranted references to oqs-openssh.

* [no] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [no] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Created this PR to "balance out" https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh/pull/157 (for the avoidance of doubt: I don't want to change the status of that sub project in the absence of a maintainer, but just cannot watch on users repeatedly having the same problems with "OQS stuff": We should _reduce_ the time people need to invest to use PQC code, not waste it).

issue.title: Can't find LibOQS library
issue.body:
Hi,
I'm following the instructions provided to build the project but, still, I always bump into the following error: configure: error: *** Can't find LibOQS library (see config.log for details) ***

This happens on the last step while running `sudo ./oqs-scripts/build_openssh.sh`.

I'm running Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS (Focal Fossa). I cannot find any relevant information on the config.log file as suggested by the error. 

Has anyone faced the same issue?

Thanks in advance!

comment.body: Thanks for the report and the solution, @luis-at -- took this as the basis for #157. If you see value in this project, please let us know and possibly consider contributing via PR's in the future.

issue.title: oqs_tlssig fails against OpenSSL 3.2.1
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
`oqs_tlssig` fails being built against OpenSSL 3.2.1

**To Reproduce**
Build liboqs and OQS provider against OpenSSL 3.2
make test

**Expected behavior**
Test passes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: CentOS 10
 - OpenSSL version 3.2.1
 - oqsprovider version 0.5.3

**Additional context**
Diagnostics (see also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/357) is
```
4: SSL_accept() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000076:SSL routines:tls_choose_sigalg:no suitable signature algorithm:ssl/t1_lib.c:3774:
4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
4:   TLS-SIG handshake test failed: dilithium2, return code: -5
```

Can it be related to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/22779?

comment.body: The problem is caused by interfering with RHEL/Fedora system-wide configuration. Thanks for your assistance!

issue.title: Getting message "too weak" when launching openssl server
issue.body:
I have installed successfully the oqs-provider and have enabled both the default and the oqsprovider providers in the /etc/ssl/openssl.cnf file. I'm replicating the process as described in the USAGE.md. I first create certificates and keys via:

```
openssl req -x509 -new -newkey dilithium3 -keyout dilithium3_CA.key -out dilithium3_CA.crt -nodes -subj "/CN=test CA" -days 365 -config /etc/ssl/openssl.cnf
openssl genpkey -algorithm dilithium3 -out dilithium3_srv.key
openssl req -new -newkey dilithium3 -keyout dilithium3_srv.key -out dilithium3_srv.csr -nodes -subj "/CN=test server" -config /etc/ssl/openssl.cnf
openssl x509 -req -in dilithium3_srv.csr -out dilithium3_srv.crt -CA dilithium3_CA.crt -CAkey dilithium3_CA.key -CAcreateserial -days 365
```

Then I try to launch the server via the provided command but I get the following error:
```
openssl s_server -cert dilithium3_srv.crt -key dilithium3_srv.key -www -tls1_3 -groups kyber768:frodo640shake
Using default temp DH parameters
error setting certificate
4077C88E967F0000:error:0A00018E:SSL routines:SSL_CTX_use_certificate:ca md too weak:../ssl/ssl_rsa.c:221:
```

Any idea?

comment.body:
> Any idea?

"ca md too weak" also can be an indication of `oqsprovider` not being properly operating/registered. So please run `openssl list -providers` and `openssl list -signature-algorithms` to ascertain all PQ algs are properly enabled. Then also try to parse the cert using `openssl x509...` to see which (also MD) alg is encoded.

issue.title: oqs_tlssig fails against OpenSSL 3.2.1
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
`oqs_tlssig` fails being built against OpenSSL 3.2.1

**To Reproduce**
Build liboqs and OQS provider against OpenSSL 3.2
make test

**Expected behavior**
Test passes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: CentOS 10
 - OpenSSL version 3.2.1
 - oqsprovider version 0.5.3

**Additional context**
Diagnostics (see also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/357) is
```
4: SSL_accept() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000076:SSL routines:tls_choose_sigalg:no suitable signature algorithm:ssl/t1_lib.c:3774:
4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
4:   TLS-SIG handshake test failed: dilithium2, return code: -5
```

Can it be related to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/22779?

comment.body:
The command 
```
OPENSSL_MODULES=`pwd`/lib/ `pwd`/test/oqs_test_tlssig "oqsprovider" `pwd`/../test/openssl-ca.cnf `pwd`/test/tmp
```
fails because system openssl configuration file is read and it includes crypto-policies implying strict limits of the signature algorithms.

The command 
```
OPENSSL_CONF= OPENSSL_MODULES=`pwd`/lib/ `pwd`/test/oqs_test_tlssig "oqsprovider" `pwd`/../test/openssl-ca.cnf `pwd`/test/tmp
```
passes

**Expected behavior**

**Additional context**

```

4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
```

comment.body:
My current workaround is local to my `.spec` file. 

I think it's worth setting the `OPENSSL_CONF` value either to empty line or to  the path to the `test/openssl-ca.cnf` configuration file which is passed as an argument in your test suite.

comment.body:
> I think it's worth setting the OPENSSL_CONF value either to empty line or to the path to the test/openssl-ca.cnf configuration file which is passed as an argument in your test suite.

This is somewhat surprising (or outright confusing): This means that a call to [OSSL_LIB_CTX_load_config](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/38c1f30ad7fc7dcf743a21a000befcb376b4102a/test/test_common.c#L50) is at least influenced (not to say overruled) by setting of "OPENSSL_CONF". Is this documented somewhere? I didn't find anything in https://www.openssl.org/docs/man3.0/man3/OSSL_LIB_CTX_load_config.html...

https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/fbce6ebf706cdd273f2569edfea7ade106426e0b/util/wrap.pl.in#L47-L48

issue.title: Support Falcon PADDED format
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Support the fixed-size PADDED format for Falcon signatures and update the existing Falcon code (which intends to implements the COMPRESSED format) to bring it in line with the spec. Reenable Falcon-1024 in weekly extended KAT tests, as it should now pass.

A couple of points to make review simpler:
- The only differences between the COMPRESSED and PADDED code should be contained in `api.h` and `pqclean.c`. It's probably worth looking at a side-by-side diff of these: for example, `pqclean_falcon-512-padded_clean/pqclean.c` vs `pqclean_falcon-512_clean/pqclean.c`.
- There are no NIST KATs available for the PADDED variant, so I generated my own from the Falcon reference implementation: see https://github.com/SWilson4/falcon-padded-KATs.
- The corresponding upstream PR is PQClean/PQClean#530.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Fixes #1561 and #1608.

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [x] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [x] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> > @Frauschi Can you please take a look at the [Zephyr test failure](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/actions/runs/8086936503/job/22097805629?pr=1710)? It looks like an out-of-storage error to me, and I'm unsure of the best way to resolve it. The same test fails on the current `main`, so it's not specific to this PR.
> 
> Indeed, what does "No space left on device" mean in this context? Also FYI, @Frauschi we're aiming of doing a `liboqs` release containing this PR early next week so resolving this quickly would be very helpful & appreciated.

I just created PR #1714 that should fix the failing Zephyr CI tests. The problem was the Zephyr installation that has been created within the test environment. A default Zephyr installation is several GBs in size, apparently overfilling the disk space of the Github runner. Hence, the "No space left on device".

issue.title: oqs_tlssig fails against OpenSSL 3.2.1
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
`oqs_tlssig` fails being built against OpenSSL 3.2.1

**To Reproduce**
Build liboqs and OQS provider against OpenSSL 3.2
make test

**Expected behavior**
Test passes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: CentOS 10
 - OpenSSL version 3.2.1
 - oqsprovider version 0.5.3

**Additional context**
Diagnostics (see also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/357) is
```
4: SSL_accept() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000076:SSL routines:tls_choose_sigalg:no suitable signature algorithm:ssl/t1_lib.c:3774:
4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
4:   TLS-SIG handshake test failed: dilithium2, return code: -5
```

Can it be related to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/22779?

comment.body:

issue.title: oqs_tlssig fails against OpenSSL 3.2.1
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
`oqs_tlssig` fails being built against OpenSSL 3.2.1

**To Reproduce**
Build liboqs and OQS provider against OpenSSL 3.2
make test

**Expected behavior**
Test passes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: CentOS 10
 - OpenSSL version 3.2.1
 - oqsprovider version 0.5.3

**Additional context**
Diagnostics (see also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/357) is
```
4: SSL_accept() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000076:SSL routines:tls_choose_sigalg:no suitable signature algorithm:ssl/t1_lib.c:3774:
4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
4:   TLS-SIG handshake test failed: dilithium2, return code: -5
```

Can it be related to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/22779?

comment.body:
> OpenSSL explicitly establishes variables in its test scripts: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/fbce6ebf706cdd273f2569edfea7ade106426e0b/util/wrap.pl.in#L47-L48

OK.... that may explain why the behaviour is as it is. But it should be documented that an API call which (is supposed to) set a config can be influenced (may one even say "crippled"?) by a global config variable. IMO the behaviour should be fixed to not allow this: An explicit API call should always overrule a global "default setting" variable. Thanks for raising the discussion.

issue.title: Documentation fails to build corrrectly

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working; high priority to fix

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
```text
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/sig/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/
Generating XML output for the main page
/Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/README.md:17: error: unable to resolve reference to 'linuxmacos' for \ref command
Running plantuml with JAVA...
type lookup cache used 152/65536 hits=476 misses=152
symbol lookup cache used 186/65536 hits=566 misses=186
finished...
Exiting...
FAILED: CMakeFiles/gen_docs /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/build/CMakeFiles/gen_docs 
cd /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs && /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/scripts/run_doxygen.sh /opt/local/bin/doxygen /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/docs/.Doxyfile /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/build
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```


**To Reproduce**
Clone and run the build.


**Expected behavior**
Successful generation of docs, of course.

Like
```text
Generating XML output for page options-for-configuring-liboqs-builds
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/common/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/kem/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/common/rand/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/sig/
Generate XML output for dir /Users/ur20980/src/liboqs/src/
Generating XML output for the main page
Running plantuml with JAVA...
type lookup cache used 152/65536 hits=476 misses=152
symbol lookup cache used 186/65536 hits=566 misses=186
finished...

real	0m0.698s
user	0m0.159s
sys	0m0.108s

Built Doxygen documentation
```


**Fix**
_Note: fix includes updating `.Doxygen` to conform to v1.9.8._

```diff
diff --git a/README.md b/README.md
index 7a51186fe..f9b49615d 100644
--- a/README.md
+++ b/README.md
@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@ liboqs is an open source C library for quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms.
                - [Limitations and Security](#limitations-and-security)
                        - [Platform limitations](#platform-limitations)
        - [Quickstart](#quickstart)
-               - [Linux/macOS](#linuxmacos)
+               - [Linux/macOS](#linux/macOS)
                - [Windows](#windows)
                - [Cross compilation](#cross-compilation)
        - [Documentation](#documentation)
```

and please do
```sh
$ cd docs
$ doxygen -u .Doxyfile
```

comment.body:
> And yes, please feel free to do the PR yourself. ;-)

[Thaaaanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_Space).

issue.title: p384_mlkem1024 hybrid added
issue.body:
We would like to use a NIST P curve + ML-KEM hybrid and compliance reasons would mandate using P-384 and ML-KEM-1024.
We found that P-384 is the most accepted P-curve. See [CNSA 1.0](https://media.defense.gov/2021/Sep/27/2002862527/-1/-1/0/CNSS%20WORKSHEET.PDF).
From the ML-KEM variants, level 5 will be the most widely accepted. See [CNSA 2.0](https://media.defense.gov/2022/Sep/07/2003071834/-1/-1/0/CSA_CNSA_2.0_ALGORITHMS_.PDF).
Having a P-384 + ML-KEM-1024 hybrid could be useful.

comment.body: Thanks for the contribution. Merged.

issue.title: Implementation of Composite Sig
issue.body:
This is an implementation of the version 10 [Composite Signatures For Use In Internet PKI](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/).
Current status of this work:
- I'm working on fixing the issues pointed by the Git Actions workflow tests.
- There will be alterations to update this for version 11 when it is released.
- To be precise with the IETF draft, we need to wait for ML-DSA-ipd to be implemented.

comment.body:
@feventura @SWilson4 Would you mind sharing your thoughts (at least with each other) as to which of your two PRs should be merged first?

My suggestion would be to merge Falcon-padded first such as to allow the Composite's to also support those. Any other opinion good for me, as long as the two of you agree with each other in order to minimize your respective effort re-basing.

issue.title: oqs_tlssig fails against OpenSSL 3.2.1
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
`oqs_tlssig` fails being built against OpenSSL 3.2.1

**To Reproduce**
Build liboqs and OQS provider against OpenSSL 3.2
make test

**Expected behavior**
Test passes

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: CentOS 10
 - OpenSSL version 3.2.1
 - oqsprovider version 0.5.3

**Additional context**
Diagnostics (see also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/pull/357) is
```
4: SSL_accept() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000076:SSL routines:tls_choose_sigalg:no suitable signature algorithm:ssl/t1_lib.c:3774:
4: SSL_connect() failed returning -1, SSL error 1. 000003FF947FADE0:error:0A000410:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:ssl/tls alert handshake failure:ssl/record/rec_layer_s3.c:865:SSL alert number 40
4:   TLS-SIG handshake test failed: dilithium2, return code: -5
```

Can it be related to https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/22779?

comment.body:
I would be concerned if OPENSSL_CONF had this impact too -why else explicitly load the config?

I'm not very familiar with liboqs, but wanted to understand this, so I may have made a mistake in the build process, but this is what I got in a clean vm (ubuntu 22.04 x86_64) [ ** please check my build invocations ** ]

First I built from a clean copy of  https://www.openssl.org/source/openssl-3.2.1.tar.gz (in ~/src/openssl-3.2.1)
```
LIBRPATH=`pwd`/deploy/lib ./Configure --prefix=`pwd`/deploy --openssldir=`pwd`/deploy '-Wl,-rpath,$(LIBRPATH)'
make
make test
```
Then for liboqs (up to date with main)
```
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/home/jonesn/src/openssl-3.2.1/deploy -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON -DOQS_USE_OPENSSL=ON -DOPENSSL_ROOT_DIR=/home/jonesn/src/openssl-3.2.1/deploy/lib64  -GNinja ..
ninja run_tests
ninja install
```
Then finally the oqsprovider (up to date with main)
```
mkdir build && cd build
cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/home/jonesn/src/openssl-3.2.1/deploy -Dliboqs_DIR=/home/jonesn/src/liboqs/build/src/cmake  -DOPENSSL_ROOT_DIR=/home/jonesn/src/openssl-3.2.1/deploy/lib64  -GNinja ..
ninja
ninja test
```

With this done, oqs_tlssig seemed ok:
```
➜  build git:(main) ✗ ninja test                                                                                              git:(main↑78|…1
[0/1] Running tests...
Test project /home/jonesn/src/oqs-provider/build
    Start 1: oqs_signatures
1/5 Test #1: oqs_signatures ...................   Passed    5.56 sec
    Start 2: oqs_kems
2/5 Test #2: oqs_kems .........................   Passed    0.88 sec
    Start 3: oqs_groups
3/5 Test #3: oqs_groups .......................   Passed    1.07 sec
    Start 4: oqs_tlssig
4/5 Test #4: oqs_tlssig .......................   Passed    4.06 sec
    Start 5: oqs_endecode
5/5 Test #5: oqs_endecode .....................   Passed   10.64 sec

100% tests passed, 0 tests failed out of 5

Total Test time (real) =  22.21 sec
```
I also explicitly set OPENSSL_CNF (as it was null) prior to the test, pointing to my system level config (not qs).
Finally I 'broke' my (system) openssl.cnf so it was invalid. openssl app (either system, or my build of 3.2.1) would fail. Again, the tests ran ok (expected, as the config shouldn't be referred to)


Does this help? Perhaps we need to inspect the build config more closely

comment.body: I run my tests on Fedora/RHEL/CentOS. They have system wide tuning in global configuration file affecting SignatureAlgorithms for TLS. I am not sure if Ubuntu touches this parameter or not.

Current status of this work:

comment.body:
> @feventura @SWilson4 Would you mind sharing your thoughts (at least with each other) as to which of your two PRs should be merged first?
> 
> My suggestion would be to merge Falcon-padded first such as to allow the Composite's to also support those. Any other opinion good for me, as long as the two of you agree with each other in order to minimize your respective effort re-basing.

> @feventura @SWilson4 Would you mind sharing your thoughts (at least with each other) as to which of your two PRs should be merged first?
> 
> My suggestion would be to merge Falcon-padded first such as to allow the Composite's to also support those. Any other opinion good for me, as long as the two of you agree with each other in order to minimize your respective effort re-basing.
